Let $f(n)$ be maximal such that there exists a set $A$ of $n$ points in $\mathbb{R}^4$ in which every $x\in A$ has at least $f(n)$ points in $A$ equidistant from $x$.

Is it true that $f(n)\leq \frac{n}{2}+O(1)$?



Avis, Erd\H{o}s, and Pach \cite{AEP88} proved that\[\frac{n}{2}+2 \leq f(n) \leq (1+o(1))\frac{n}{2}.\]This was proved by Swanepoel \cite{Sw13}, who in fact proved more generally that, in any finite set $A\subset \mathbb{R}^4$ of size $n$ and any choice of distance $d(x)$ for each $x\in A$,\[\sum_{x\in A}\sum_{y\in A}1_{\lvert x-y\rvert =d(x)}\leq \tfrac{1}{2}n^2+O(n),\]and proved similar results for finite point sets in higher dimensional space.




References


[AEP88] Avis, David and Erd\H{o}s, Paul and Pach, J\'anos, Repeated distances in space. Graphs Combin. (1988), 207--217.

[Sw13] Swanepoel, Konrad J., Favorite distances in high dimensions. (2013), 499--519.
